text: <@U0DN73LR2|ciro> has joined the channel
Hello everyone!
<@U0DQZFUMP|edu> has joined the channel
<@U07STTF5W|rcreanga> has joined the channel

Wasn't sure if this was the right place to post (let me know!), but just wanted to see what everyone thought of this article (<http://hackajob.co/blog/technical-recruitment-is-broken-we-need-your-help-to-fix-it/>)

I guess pretty much any Android/mobile job has technical testing at some point, and some companies do other things, but what do you guys think?

I think <@U0542GLTE> would probably side more with this article than I would as I am not very interested in someones ability to properly solve some random off the wall question in an interview after they have probably been stressing all day and already answered a hundred questions. Its just not a good time to ask someone something complex imo yet we do it anyways.

Imagine taking your SAT after running a marathon, clearly that would be a bad idea. So why do we do it at all?

I will agree asking the hard stuff up front is probably better for everyone. Additionally by simply asking a person their skill sets on a huge list of android api’s I have been able to do what I think is a more genuine assessment. Usually in the process you can tell a few things like can I even work with this person? Does this person even know anything about android? If they have done something interesting that maybe they forgot about, it usually comes up now and that can be an enlightening conversation.

I just don’t see how you can get that kind of data out of asking a puzzle and then using it as an ‘ah ha see they lied’ when it could just be ‘oh they aren’t that great on the spot but maybe they are actually a great developer they just dont work well in situations like this'
in a meeting. I’ll throw some thoughts in later.
you’ll do it now <@U0542GLTE> we don’t care about your meeting
^ahaha
at least the article is advocating for more targeted questions rather than random brain teasers and stuff your interviewer took off the internet
<@U055GGAHS>:  totally agree
but really the TLDR of what im saying is I’ll take a good developer and someone I can work with/self motivated over someone that is some kind of super genius at some specific thing
<@U0546QERR>: yep, I would agree its better like that
if we are on the fence with people we try to offer them a temp job which has worked well here in the past
like people that seem really motivated but don’t have the experience, try to see if they could work and if they dont at least they arent out a lot cause you cut them some pay
i think thats something else that needs to change, employers ask a LOT of candidates and even when they are covering things like travel that doesn’t pay my bills

i get that you need people that can think critically and solve problems, but you can usually tell if they have that skill by asking about work they've done before as well, and not some random algorithm which may or may not be their strong set

Imagine doing anything (let alone something requiring thought) after a marathon haha.

But I agree with <@U055GGAHS> . Interview situations are such a different ballgame. People can be completely different in those situations, and trying to catch them out with a test rather than  focus on what they're like and learning about them in conversation seems a bit of a waste of their time and your own.

Google being the worst offender imo, i spent days studying random things just hoping I studied the right stuff and I put in a hell of a  lot of effort into ultimately getting rejected and it was pretty obviously imo that I was going to get rejected once I got onsite and got into the second interview

We try to be as nice as possible, the biggest brain teaser seems to be the challenge we send them after the initial phone screen (but it’s not - <@U0548MM6B> has seen it and can confirm). Everything else is just a discussion, and some pair programming to see how they are to work with.
based on that experience I don’t want to bother again
it was too much risk for what is questionable pay off
<@U053PPGDC> pair programming sounds fun and a good assessment of an actual skill you need to work on a team
I like reading peoples stackoverflow and github accounts
you can learn an invaluable amount of information from that
do you twitter stalk?
nope
if they dont provide the information I don’t go looking for it, its a direct question ‘can I look at your stackoverflow and github accounts?'
<@U053PPGDC>: lol yeah that first screen really filters out some idiots for you guys :joy:
I’ve stopped answering on SO since I realised that it’s a community of people who cares only about rating, reputation and power.
welcome to the internet, I guess
lol
also yeah google really sucks. if i don't get the job there i would have wasted at least 10-20+ hours studying this junk that i'll probably forget in 2 months
/giphy you have no power here
really giphy? really?
Gihpy just has more rating on SO than you :smile:
Pair programming is a good way. If you ask someone idk, to make you a new activity with X and Y, and you can sit by them while they do it
you’ll not just see their code and mostly skill level
you see how they use the tool
but their use of IDE and stuff like shortcuts
which is the most important
exactly
yeah, a lot of  times it is the less they touch the mouse, the more time they probably spent in the IDE
<http://giphy.com/gifs/RX3vhj311HKLe> after this <@U055GGAHS> haha?
yep.. but giphy is too fucking stupid to do 100% word matches
cause that would like.. make sense
1st result under 'power'...then again I did have to go to <http://giphy.com|giphy.com> to do that
`Giphy could not match giphy sucks`
usually it matches that lol
/giphy #echo giphy sucks

So, first thing, it’s not about whether or not the person can solve the problem. It’s about working with the team. I never give a candidate a question that the team has not already done. They are usually not super difficult, and I always draw the data out. So if its a tree, they have a visual reference, linked list etc. The whole goal is you know three things. The people in the room have already solved the problem, aka have experience, how willing are you to ask for help and collaborate. They aren’t going to do it all for you, but can definitely point you in correct directions and stop you before you make it too complicated. The person also gets to pick which problem they want, and they are all different as far as. Some are longer but straight forward, and some were shorter but more difficult to wrap your head around. However, it was about working with the team thats it. 

We always started with the `for (int i = 0;` problem and then told them how stupidly some of us solved it (kmatt and greg usually get made fun of for their solutions) and kind of relax the atmosphere. It’s not like a 1 on 1 you’re right or wrong issue.
However, I think the whole goal of the article is that recruiting companies need to get better about what the hell they are actually hiring for and finding candidates that have that skillset.

I could go _interview_ for a javascript job, but guess what, it’s totally fucking pointless, because I am not qualified for it. Doesn’t stop every recruiter from asking me if I want a job doing HTML and CSS.

At the end of the day it's all about how they collaborate and get on with the team. Testing/interview scenarios are short, self-contained by nature, but it's only one assessing factor (past work and all that is just as, if not more, useful in judging technical ability) that's just as good at figuring out team fit.

But yeah I think that's probably the point of the post. A recruiter could ask you to apply to job XYZ even if XYZ is not your core expertise. Ick..not sure what the reason is though. Them not paying too much attention to your details, etc when they call/email up?

>The person also gets to pick which problem they want, and they are all different
this is something i wish all interviewers would do. i'm pretty good with certain concepts but for some questions if i don't know the trick, i'm just not going to figure it out. doesn't mean i suck at everything :confused:
and at a lot of places it just takes one bad interview out of 4 or 5 to get you rejected

One of our friends in Orlando gave a interview meetup to some junior devs two nights ago, and it’s spurred some good convo. Here is something I found interesting 

> It makes it a lot easier if you do things publicly. If you've got Github projects, open source, a blog ... Something that can be referenced to evaluate your tech skill prior to the interview process, then the interview can be reduced to mostly soft skills assessment and culture fit. Otherwise, you'll need to be extra prepared to do technical challenges on the spot, in the interview. Because your resume is just words on a page. A sufficiently skilled word smith can easily appear to be more competent than they really are.

<@U0542GLTE>: In general, I’d agree, but in how many instances does that occur? like wonder really how many times they check the applicant’s github and say “oh ok he knows what he’s doing, don’t need to test him with random algorithms"
yeah i'd still reckon if you stumble on an algorithm they'll still walk away with a bad taste
yeah, like even if Jake came they’d probably be like “uhh, I think he was a bit insecure"
or rather, one could do a sort of walkthrough through one of their projects to demonstrate their understanding
my github is all over the place anyway. my last project is all stuffed into MainActivity while this project is a MVP masterpiece... so to speak :smile:
I always ask people for three files that they think are their best work from their github
a la the Why Programming Sucks post. Everyone has their snowflakes and beautiful files and classes
README.md :troll:
LICENSE.txt
actually, README.md could be a very good indicator of a good engineer
depends on if they follow README-driven development or not
